location: Champaign Police Department
summary: 1/14/1970: Suspected Black militants threw two firebombs into the Champaign Police Department in Champaign, Illinois, United States.  The building was damaged and one police officer was severely burned.
weapdetail: Firebomb thrown through window
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.
scite3: Peter F. Nardulli and Jeffrey M. Stonecash, "Politics, Professionalism, and Urban Services," Oelgeschlager, Gunn & Hain, Publishers, Inc. 1981.

location: Manhattan
summary: 1/25/1970: Responding to what authorities believe was a fake report to lure police to Manhattan, New York, United States, Patrolmen William Kivlehan and Ralph Bax were shot at from a rooftop by unknown perpetrators after they got out of their car.  Officer Kivlehan was hit five times and officer Bax was hit three times.  Both policemen survived.
target1: New York Police Officers responding to a call in Harlem
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Nine thirty-caliber cartridges from a carbine and eleven nine-millimeter shells
propcomment: One window in a building shattered
addnotes: Police do not believe that this attack was related to the shooting of a police officer in Queens hours later (197001260003).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Martin Arnold, "Harlem Area Sealed Off As Police Hunt Snipers," New York Times, January 27, 1970.
scite3: "2 Policemen Wounded by Sniper Fire," New York Times, January 26, 1970.

location: Parking lot of police station
summary: 2/13/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated two dynamite bombs in the parking lot of the Berkeley Police Station in California, United States, during a shift change.  Seven police officers were injured, three cars were destroyed, and windows were shattered at nearby buildings.
motive: To intimidate the police.
weapdetail: Homemade dynamite time bombs
propcomment: Three cars destroyed.  Numerous other vehicles damaged.  Windows shattered at adjacent buildings.
addnotes: The bombs detonated 30 seconds apart.  The bombs used in the attack were similar to the devices used in the attack against a police station in San Francisco three days later (197002160001).  There was a contentious City Council debate earlier in the week as to whether the police department should receive a helicopter.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bombs Injure 2 Policemen in Berkeley," Washington Post, February 14, 1970.
scite3: "San Francisco Bomb Injured 7 Policemen," Washington Post, February 18, 1970.

summary: 2/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators set fire to a building housing an R.O.T.C. storage area at the University of Oregon in Eugene, Oregon, United States.  One fireman was injured fighting the blaze and the men's physical education building sustained an estimated $350,000 in damages.  The incident took place a week after the university voted to retain the R.O.T.C. program.
target1: R.O.T.C. storage area, University of Oregon
motive: To protest the University of Oregon's decision to retain the R.O.T.C. program
weapdetail: Arson
propcomment: R.O.T.C. storage area destroyed.  Four class rooms and two offices were destroyed.
addnotes: The fire was set in the R.O.T.C. storage area.  David Boggs was the fireman who was injured.
scite1: Mike Stahlberg, "Clues Sought for Cause of UO Fire," Eugene Register-Guard, February 17, 1970.
scite2: "Students Impede Firemen; R.O.T.C. Offices in Ruins," The Milwaukee Journal, February 17, 1970.
scite3: Emily Mosen, "The Reserve Officers' Training Corps: Protests and Perspectives on the University of Oregon Campus in 1969 and 1970," University of Oregon, March 14, 2005.

summary: 3/5/1970: Unknown Puerto Rican Nationalists assassinated two United States Navy personal stationed in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The incident was in response to the death of Antonia Martinez Lagaras, who was shot and killed during a confrontation between students and police in front of the R.O.T.C. building at the University of Puerto Rico, Rio Piedras a day earlier.
target1: Two members of the United States Navy
motive: To protest United States presence in Puerto Rico and revenge the death of Antonia Martinez Lagares
addnotes: Conflicting reports attribute the incident to the Armed Commandos of Liberation and the Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA).
scite1: Committee on the Judiciary  United States Senate, "Terroristic Activity: The Cuban Connection in Puerto Rico; Castro's Hand in Puerto Rican and U.S. Terrorism," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: William Sater, "Puerto Rican Terrorists: A Possible Threat to U.S. Energy Installations?," RAND, October 1981.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and CommuniquÃ©s from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

location: Floor of car
summary: 3/9/1970: A bomb exploded in the car of Ralph Featherstone and William Payne, members of the Student non-violent Coordinating Committee and supporters of H. Rap Brown, while they were driving in Bel Air, Maryland, United States.  Both men died as a result of the blast.  Police suspected that the bomb exploded prematurely and was intended for H. Rap Brown's trial scheduled to be held  at the Harford County Courthouse   Many members of the radical Black community believed that the bomb was set off by White Racists or the police.  The next day, a bomb was detonated at Dorchester County Courthouse, the original location of Brown's trial, by an unknown perpetrator.
motive: The suspected motive was to disrupt the trial of H. Rap Brown
weapdetail: Police believed that the bomb had an electric battery
propcomment: Car was damaged
addnotes: This attack is linked with 197003100002.  H. Rap Brown was charged with arson and inciting a riot.  However, he never showed up for his trial and was finally apprehended in 1972.  The bombings occurred at a time of a lot of racial tension in Maryland.   Immediately after the bombing, there were numerous bomb threats to public buildings in the Baltimore and Washington DC areas.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Homer Bigart, "Maryland Hunts Woman In Blast," New York Times, March 12, 1970.
scite3: Peter A. Jay, "Bomb Threats in Area," Washington Post, March 13, 1970.

location: Living room, outside of house
summary: 3/16/1970: Unknown perpetrators threw four firebombs at the house of Councilman Norris Gregory in San Bernardino, California, United States.  He received minor burns attempting to put out the fire and the house sustained an estimated $4,000 in damages.  Gregory was the first and only Black councilman in San Bernadino at the time.
motive: To protest African Americans sitting on the San Bernardino city council
weapdetail: Firebombs
propcomment: The house was damaged and the drapes were set on fire
addnotes: At the time of the firebombing Norris Gregory was facing a recall election.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Four Black Churches Fire Bombed in Texas," Jet Magazine, March 25, 1971.

location: In front of his car
summary: 3/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators shot and killed Burton I. Gordin, the director of the Michigan Civil Rights Commission, in a downtown garage in Detroit, Michigan, United States.  Police suspected that this incident might have been politically motivated as no money was stolen from Gordin's wallet.
motive: To protest the civil rights movement
weapdetail: Three shots fired
addnotes: The police were unsure if this incident was an attempted robbery, with the perpetrators too frightened to take the targets money, or if it was an assassination.
scite1: Jerry M. Flint, "Civil Rights Chief In Michigan Slain," New York Times, March 21, 1970.
scite2: "No Motive of Suspect Seen In Slaying of Rights Official," Washington Post, March 22, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

location: Manhattan
summary: 3/21/1970: In a series of related attacks, a group called Puerto Rican Resistance claimed credit for two incendiary devices that ignited at Alexander's Department Store in Manhattan, New York, United States.  One person was injured but the firebomb caused minor damage.
motive: Promote Puerto Rican Independence
weapdetail: Cigarette box containing flammable material, batteries, and a watch mechanism
propcomment: Merchandise was slightly damaged
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003210002.  Four Ecuadorians were originally detained for the bombings but they were eventually released.  The Puerto Rican Resistance claimed credit for the incident in a letter to the New York Daily News.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Robert D. McFadden, "2 Stores Targets of Arson Devices," New York Times, March 22, 1970.
scite3: "Chicago 'Bomb Factory' Probe Seeks Links to Those in N.Y.," Washington Post, April 1, 1970.

location: Manhattan
summary: 3/22/1970: In a series of related attacks, a suspected member of the Black Panther Party detonated a pipe bomb at the Electric Circus Discotheque in Manhattan New York, United States.  Seventeen people were injured and the building sustained minor damages.
weapdetail: Pipe bomb made of dynamite and small caliber ammunition with a clock detonator
propcomment: Portable stage destroyed
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197003220001 and 197003220002.  Originally the police believed that the attack was part of a dispute between Hells Angels, but eventually police accused Ishmael Brown, a member of the Black Panther Party, of being the perpetrator.   The Black Panther Party denied any involvement in the incident.  Brown was killed when a bomb accidentally blew up in his apartment in what the police determined was a bomb factory.  Police accused his roommate Godwin Bernard, who was injured in the apartment blast, of being the perpetrator in 197003220001 and 197003220002
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Michael Knight, "15 at the Electric Circus Injured in Bomb Explosion," New York Times, March 23, 1970.
scite3: Lawrence Van Gelder, "Injured Bombing Suspect Is Arraigned in Hospital," New York Times, August 12, 1970.

summary: 4/11/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed a storage tank at the Dow Chemical Company located north of Freeport, Texas, United States.  Five people received minor injuries from flying glass and an estimated $250,000 in damages was caused to the facilities.
target1: Dow Chemical Company plant, Freeport Texas
weapdetail: Explosion and fire
propcomment: Storage tank damaged
scite1: "5 Persons Hurt In Plant Blast", The Victoria Advocate, April 12, 1970.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 4/17/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panther Party ambushed a police paddy wagon carrying two police officers and four prisoners in Oakland, California, United States.  Both police officers were critically wounded.  In the ensuing car chase, the perpetrators threw fragmentation grenades at police vehicles causing major damage.  Two of the assailants were eventually captured.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Automatic weapons and fragmentation grenades
propcomment: Police vehicles heavily damaged
addnotes: The Black Panther Party denied involvement in the attack, however, one of the captured assailants, Lewis R. Williams, was a captain in the BPP.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "5 Killed by Tornado in Mississippi," Washington Post, April 20, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Queens
summary: 4/19/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed a pipe bomb in a corrections officer's car parked outside of the House of Detention in Queens, New York, United States, where ten Black Panthers members were held.  The bomb failed to explode and was discovered  after an unknown individual phoned the police stating "we're going to blow up the jail in a half hour.  Free the Panther 21."
motive: To coerce the government to free the Panther 21 from prison.
weapdetail: Lighted cigarette attached to bomb fuse
addnotes: The lighted cigarette burned out before detonating the bomb.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Bomb Found at Jail, Dynamite at a Bank," New York Times, April 20, 1970.

location: University of Kansas
summary: 4/20/1970: Unknown perpetrators firebombed the Student Union at the University of Kansas, Lawrence, United States.  There were no casualties but the building sustained approximately $3,000,000 in damages.
motive: This attack occurred during heightened racial tensions in Lawrence Kansas.
weapdetail: Arson
propcomment: The roof caved in and the top two floors of the buildings were gutted
addnotes: Authorities were unsure whether the perpetrators were Black or White.  After the attack, a curfew was instituted in Lawrence and the National Guard was called in.  Before the fire broke out, there were reports of loud explosions at the Student Union.
scite1: Rusty L. Monhollon, "This is America? The Sixties in Lawrence, Kansas," Palgrave, 2002.
scite2: Deborah C. Kidwell, "Building the Vietnam Veterans Memorial at the University of Kansas," Kansas History: A Journal of the Central Plains, 2007.
scite3: "Curfew Ordered in Illinois Town," Baltimore Sun, April 25, 1970.

location: West Baltimore
summary: 4/24/1970: Three members of the Black Panthers Party opened fire on a police vehicle parked in Baltimore, Maryland, United States.  Patrolman Donald Sager was killed and police officer Stanley Sierakowski was critically wounded but survived.  The perpetrators were under orders from the Black Panthers to kill police.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: .45 caliber semi-automatic pistol and .38 caliber pistol
addnotes: The killings were part of a Black Panthers initiation ritual.  All three perpetrators were convicted and received life sentences.
scite1: George J. Hiltner, "City Panther is Convicted of Murder," Washington Post, January 16, 1970.
scite2: Laurie Willis, "Judge Affirms 1972 Life Term," Baltimore Sun, December 5, 1972.
scite3: George J. Hiltner, "Panther Gets Life, 15 Years in Police Killings," Washington Post, June 17, 1972.

location: Metal trash container
summary: 4/27/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb on a street in Iowa City, Iowa, United States.  There was two injuries and twelve businesses were damaged at a total estimated cost of $20,000.
weapdetail: Explosives
propcomment: Twelve businesses damaged
addnotes: The bombing occurred one block away from the University of Iowa.  Kathy Scharf and her mother Merlin Edwards were lightly wounded in the attack.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Bill Lynch, "Note Calls La. Capitol Blast 'Revenge,'" Washington Post, April 28, 1970.

location: Yale University
summary: 5/1/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at the Ingalls Skating Rink at Yale University in New Haven, Connecticut, United States.  There were two injuries and the entrance of the building was damaged.  The attack took place during a school dance after a large demonstration protesting the trial of the Black Panther Eight.
weapdetail: Black power used for explosive
propcomment: Staircase near entrance was damaged and twenty large windows were shattered.
addnotes: The police commissioner was unsure whether the perpetrators of the attack were for or against the Black Panther Eight.  Two people were slightly injured by flying glass.  Twelve thousand people attended the demonstration.
scite1: Homar Bigart, "New Haven Rally Ends a Day Early; Attendance Down," New York Times, May 3, 1970.
scite2: "First Day Ends in Melee," Hartford Courant, May 2, 1970.
scite3: Frank Donner, "Protectors of Privilege: Red Squads and Police Repression in Urban America," University of California Press, 1990.

location: The Bronx
summary: 5/1/1970: In a series of related incidents, suspected Puerto Rican nationalists detonated two bombs at the Dale Theatre in the Bronx, New York, United States.  Ten people were injured in the attack and the theater sustained light damages.  A third bomb that did not detonate was eventually discovered.
weapdetail: Three concussion bombs
propcomment: Theater sustained minor damages
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197005010006.  Authorities believed that Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) member Carlos Feliciano was involved in the incident, but he was never charged. (See: "Charge Puerto Rican in Bombings," Chicago Defender, May 19, 1970.)
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Paul L. Montgomery, "Bronx Bombings Scored By Mayor," New York Times, May 3, 1970.
scite3: "Small Bombs Injure 17 in N.Y. Theaters," Washington Post, May 2, 1970.

location: The Bronx
summary: 5/1/1970: In a series of related incidents, Puerto Rican nationalists detonated one bomb at the Paradise Theatre in the Bronx, New York, United States.  One person was injured in the attack and the theater sustained light damages.
weapdetail: One concussion bomb
propcomment: Theater sustained minor damages
addnotes: Part of a multiple attack with 197005010005.  The attacks took place just minutes apart.  Authorities believed that Armed Revolutionary Independence Movement (MIRA) member Carlos Feliciano was involved in the incident, but he was never charged. (See: "Charge Puerto Rican in Bombings," Chicago Defender, May 19, 1970.)
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Paul L. Montgomery, "Bronx Bombings Scored By Mayor," New York Times, May 3, 1970.
scite3: "Small Bombs Injure 17 in N.Y. Theaters," Washington Post, May 2, 1970.

location: Brooklyn
summary: 5/5/1970: Unknown perpetrators detonated a bomb at the Sears, Roebuck & Company Department Store in Brooklyn, New York, United States.  Two women were injured in the blast and it is unknown if the store was damaged.
target1: Sears, Roebuck & Company, Brooklyn New York
weapdetail: Bomb believed to be hidden in a hand bag
addnotes: The explosion did not create a fire.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "2 Injured By Bomb In Brooklyn Store," New York Times, May 5, 1970.

location: Brooklyn
summary: 5/9/1970: The Stop the War Coalition claimed credit for setting fire to the Humanities Building at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University in New York, United States.  Twelve firefighters were injured fighting the blaze and the building sustained $100,000 in damages.
motive: To force Long Island University to close
weapdetail: Arson
propcomment: Offices and records destroyed on two floors of the Humanities building
addnotes: The Stop the War Coalition sent a letter to the president of Long Island University warning that there would be more attacks against the university unless the campus closed.  Twelve firemen were treated for smoke inhalation.  This was one of many attacks against military targets within the United States following the shooting of four Kent State students by the Ohio National Guard.
scite1: William E. Farrell, "Political Action By Youth Is Goal," New York Times, May 10, 1970.
scite2: William Greider, "Fire Hit Campuses; Rallies Calm," Washington Post, May 10, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Oak Park
summary: 5/9/1970: Sacramento Police Officer Bernard Bennett was shot and killed by a sniper, suspected of being a Black Militant, as the he was patrolling the Oak Park area of Sacramento, United States, with his partner Officer Lloyd Smothers.
motive: To punish Sacramento Police officers for their treatment of African Americans
weapdetail: Sniper; a total of six bullets fired
addnotes: The bullet struck officer Bennett in the head.  This attack occurred during heightened tensions between the police and the African American community of Sacramento California.  The police originally charged seven people, with ties to various Black National organizations including the Black Panther Party, for the attack.  However,  the suspected perpetrators were acquitted of the crime during their trial due to lack of evidence.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: David Colvin, "Black Politics After the Civil Rights Movement: Activity and Beliefs in Sacramento, 1970-2000," McFarland & Company, Inc., 2009.
scite3: "Sacramento Policeman Shot," New York Times, May 11, 1970.

location: Against a wall near a transformer and fuel drums
summary: 5/13/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panthers bombed the Des Moines Police Station in Iowa, United States.  Two people were injured and the attack caused an estimated $200,000 in damages.
motive: To kill police officers
weapdetail: Dynamite explosion
propcomment: Holes in the wall, two-hundred and eighty shattered windows, around a dozen cars damaged, power outages, and windows of several surrounding buildings damaged.
addnotes: There was a bomb threat against the Des Moines Police Department a week earlier.  On May 5th 1970, a large quantity of dynamite was stolen from Quick Supply, a dynamite supply warehouse in Ankeny Iowa.  Police believed that the stolen dynamite was used by the Black Panthers in this attack as well as in four other incidents taking place in Iowa during May and June 1970 197005220003, 197006130001, 197006210001, and 197006290001).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Committee on Internal Security House of Representatives, "Black Panther Party, Part 4," U.S. Government Printing Office, October-November, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Capital Hill Area
summary: 5/15/1970: Larry G. Ward, an African American, was shot and killed by police as he attempted to bomb the Hardcastle Realty office in Seattle, Washington, United States.  The real estate office was the target of a bombing a month earlier.
weapdetail: Three sticks of dynamite taped to a fuse and blasting cap
addnotes: Police received intelligence that the realty office would be attacked and two officers were waiting at the scene.  Ward succeeded in lighting the fuse, but the bomb failed to ignite.  Hardcastle realty was previously bombed in attack 197004190002.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Public Service Strikes Hit San Diego," Washington Post, May 16, 1970.

location: 859 Hague Avenue
summary: 5/22/1970: Police Officer James Sackett is murdered by a sniper after he responded to a fake emergency call in St. Paul, Minnesota, United States.  Over thirty-five years after Sackett's death Ronald Reed and Larry Clark were convicted of the murder.  They were Black Panther wannabe's who wanted to kill a police officer.
motive: To kill police indiscriminately
weapdetail: High-powered rifle
addnotes: Constance Trimble, the former girlfriend of Ronald Reed, stated that she made the phony phone call to lure a St. Paul Police Officer.  Reed and Clark were both convicted of first-degree murder and conspiracy and sentenced to life in prison.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Shannon Prather, "Court Upholds Verdict in Cop Killings," St. Paul Pioneer Press, August 23, 2007.
scite3: "St. Paul Police Officer James Sackett, 27, Is Killed By A Shot From A High-Powered Rifle," St. Paul Pioneer Press, May 7, 2006.

location: Window well on South side of building
summary: 5/22/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panthers bombed the Ames Police Headquarters located in the city hall of Ames, Iowa, United States.  Ten people were injured and an estimated $50,000 in damage was caused.
motive: To kill police officers
weapdetail: Bomb
propcomment: Extensive damage to the south side of the building.  Two cars destroyed.  Two hundred windows of nearby hotel shattered.
addnotes: Earlier in the week, Ames City Hall received a bomb threat.  Telephone service in downtown Ames was temporarily put out of service as a result of the blast.  On May 5th 1970, a large quantity of dynamite was stolen from Quick Supply, a dynamite supply warehouse in Ankeny Iowa.  Police believed that the stolen dynamite was used by the Black Panthers in this attack as well as in four other incidents taking place in Iowa during May and June 1970 (197005130001, 197006130001, 197006210001, and 197006290001).
scite1: Committee on Internal Security House of Representatives, "Black Panther Party, Part 4," U.S. Government Printing Office, October-November, 1970.
scite2: "Ames City Hall Bombed," Ames Daily Tribune, May 22, 1970.
scite3: "Des Moines Hit By Bomb Blast," Washington Post, June 14, 1970.

location: Underneath steering wheel
summary: 6/2/1970: A disgruntled businessman is suspected of hiring hit men to assassinate Illinois State Representative William G. Barr.  A dynamite bomb exploded when Barr turned on the ignition of his Cadillac in Joliet, Illinois, United States.  The car was destroyed and Barr's right leg had to be amputated.
motive: Protest William G. Barr 's position on mental health legislation
weapdetail: Dynamite bomb connected to the ignition of the car
propcomment: Cadillac destroyed
addnotes: It is believed that a Chicago businessman was angry at Barr for attempting to introduce reform legislation concerning mental health issues in the Illinois General Assembly.  It is suspected that the businessman contacted Silas Jayne to hire the hit men.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Terry Burns, "Probe Provides Insight Into Car-Bomb Attacks," The State Journal-Register, November 17, 1995.
scite3: "Legislator's Car Bombed," New York Times, June 3, 1970.

location: Through living room window
summary: 6/9/1970: Unknown perpetrators fired two shotgun blasts into the house of Reverend Levin P. West in Newark, New Jersey, United States, in an apparent assassination attempt.  The shotgun pellets did not strike West but he was taken to  the hospital to be treated for shock.  During a highly contentious Mayoral campaign in Newark with racial overtones, West, an African American, supported the White candidate over the Black candidate.
corp1: Black supporters of Mayor Hugh Addonizio
motive: To protest Black supporters of Hugh Addonizio in the 1970 Newark mayoral campaign
weapdetail: Two shotgun blasts through living room window
propcomment: Window shattered and several shotgun pellets found in the living room wall
addnotes: The White mayoral candidate was Hugh Addonizio and the Black mayoral candidate was Kenneth Gibson.
scite1: Walter H. Waggoner, "Negro Backing Addonizio Target of Shotgun Blast," New York Times, June 10, 1970.
scite2: "Shotgun Blasts Are Fired Into Home Of Black Campaigner for Addonizio," New York Times, June 10, 1970.

summary: 6/12/1970: Unknown snipers fired on an Illinois State Police patrol attending to a fire at the Pyramid Courts housing project in Cairo, Illinois, United States.  Officer Marion Troutt was shot, but survived his wounds.  This incident took place during a period of high racial tension in Cairo.
target1: Illinois State Police in the Pyramid Courts housing project
motive: African American opposition to the police
weapdetail: Snipers
addnotes: Officer Troutt was struck in the chest and leg.  Police did not believe that this incident was linked with the attempted bombing of the Alexander County Courthouse (197006120002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Cairo Chief Disengages Bomb Device," Southeast Missourian, June 12, 1970.

location: Stairwell at basement of building
summary: 6/13/1970: Suspected members of the Black Panthers Party bombed the Des Moines Chamber of Commerce in Des Moines, Iowa, United States.  The building sustained an estimated $150,000 in damages and several people were injured from the shattered glass.
weapdetail: Dynamite
propcomment: Facility sustained heavy damages.  Debris scattered throughout a three block area.  Around two hundred and seventy five windows shattered at surrounding buildings.
addnotes: Conservatively coded the number of injuries at twenty.  It was reported that several, of the forty-five women staying at the YWCA a block away, were injured by the shattered glass.  Only one of the injured, Donna Melick, required medical treatment.  On May 5th 1970, a large quantity of dynamite was stolen from Quick Supply, a dynamite supply warehouse in Ankeny Iowa.  Police believed that the stolen dynamite was used by the Black Panthers in this attack as well as in four other incidents taking place in Iowa during May and June 1970 (197005130001, 197005220003, 197006210001, and 197006290001).  A bank in Kansas City was bombed on the same day (197006290001).
scite1: Committee on Internal Security House of Representatives, "Black Panther Party, Part 4," U.S. Government Printing Office, October-November, 1970.
scite2: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite3: "Des Moines Hit By Bomb Blast," Washington Post, June 14, 1970.

summary: 6/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a diner in Emeryville, California, United States frequented by police officers.  Three people were slightly injured and it is unknown if the diner sustained any damages.
target1: Emeryville Police Officers frequenting a local diner
weapdetail: Homemade pipe bombs
addnotes: The pipe bombs exploded during the early morning.  Police frequented the diner twenty-four hours a day.
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.

location: 74th and Union
summary: 6/19/1970: Bruce Sharp and William Redwine, both African Americans, shot and killed Police Officer Kenneth Kaner as he was sitting in his squad car in Chicago Illinois, United States.
motive: African American opposition to the police
weapdetail: .12 gauge double barreled shotgun; .38 caliber revolver
addnotes: Bruce Sharp and William Redwine and three others driving in the same car noticed Officer Kenneth Kaner sitting in his car and someone in the group shouted "let's get him" and/or "let's get his gun."
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Jody P. Weiss, State of Illinois, Prisoner Review Board, "Murdered Chicago Police Officer Kenneth Kaner on June 19, 1970." Illinois Department of Corrections, August 11, 2008.
scite3: "Races: Ambushes in Chicago," Time Magazine, August 24, 1970.

location: 643 Waller Street
summary: 6/19/1970: Police Officer Richard Radetich was shot and killed by an unknown perpetrator in San Francisco, California, United States.  While writing a ticket, a gunman pulled up to Officer Radetich in his car and shot him three times with a revolver.  The perpetrator immediately drove away.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: .38 caliber revolver
addnotes: Police originally arrested Joe Allen Johnson for the murder but released him due to lack of evidence.  The Zodiac killer is also believed to claim credit for this attack, but the authorities did not believe this was credible.  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in Northern California while they were making traffic stops (197008060004 and 197008200003).
scite1: Jim Herron Zamora, "1967-71: a Bloody Period For S.F. Police," San Francisco Chronicle, January 27, 2001.
scite2: "Chicago, Coast Policemen Shot,"  Baltimore Sun, June 20, 1970.
scite3: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.

location: West End District
summary: 6/30/1970: Two policemen, Robert M. Perry and Robert G. Beck, were shot by snipers in Plainfield, New Jersey, United States after responding to a fire at a vacant shop.  Officer Perry would eventually die from his injuries.  City officials believed that radical African Americans intentionally set the fire to lure the policemen into the area.  Firefighters fighting the blaze were also shot at.
corp1: Police and firefighters of Plainfield New Jersey
target1: Police and firefighters at the scene of a fire in the African American part of town in Plainfield New Jersey
motive: To spark community wide turmoil
weapdetail: Sniper fire; Arson
addnotes: This attack took place during heightened racial tensions in Plainfield New Jersey.  Over a year later, Police Officer Frank Buczek was killed two blocks away (197109180002).
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: Francis X. Clines, "2 Plainfield Police Shot at Fire Scene," New York Times, July 1, 1970.
scite3: Emanuel Perlmutter, "Policemen Wounded In Jersey Disorder Dies After Surgery," New York Times, July 2, 1970.

location: One hundred feet from police station
summary: 7/2/1970: Tommy L. Harper, an African American, was killed when a bomb that he was carrying prematurely exploded when he was one hundred feet away from the Compton Police Station in California, United States.  It is suspected that he was attempting to bomb the police station.  Windows were shattered at a building and automobile that were in the vicinity of the explosion.
weapdetail: A makeshift bomb connected to a clock device
propcomment: Windows of an automobile in the area and the windows of an adjacent building were shattered
scite1: Committee on Government Operations United States Senate, "Riots, Civil, and Criminal Disorders," U.S. Government Printing Office, August 6, 1970.
scite2: "Carrier of Bomb Blown To Pieces in California," Washington Post, July 3, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

summary: 7/4/1970: Two youths were hired by Frank Thurber, a member of a union affiliated with the striking Typographical Union, shot and killed Allan W. Daly at his home in San Francisco, California, United States.  Daly was a non-striking member of the San Rafael Independent Journal.
corp1: Non striking member of the San Rafael Independent Journal
motive: To protest non-participants in the San Rafael Independent Journal strike
weapdetail: .45 caliber pistol
addnotes: Allan Daly survived two weeks before finally succumbing to his wounds.  Frank Thurber belonged to the San Francisco Mailers Union.  Thurber offered Richard Wamsley and Larry Rutherford $300 to "rough up" Daly.  Thurber provided them with a weapon and drove the to Daly's home.  Printers used by non-striking members of the San Rafael Independent journal were firebombed days later (197007080002).
scite1: "Nonstriker At Paper Succumbs To Wounds," Los Angeles Times, July 17, 1970.
scite2: "Home of Nonstriking Printers Fire-Bombed; 6 Escape Injury," Los Angeles Times, July 9, 1970.
scite3: "Slayer Given Life Sentence," The Bulletin, December 10, 1970.

location: Around Kempton Street
summary: 7/11/1970: Unknown White perpetrators fired shotgun blasts indiscriminately into a crowd of African American youths in New Bedford, Massachusetts, United States.  Lester Lima was killed and Kim Holland, Randall Robinson, and Gordon Ribiro were wounded.  This attack sparked widespread rioting by the African American community of New Bedford.
target1: African Americans in New Bedford Massachusetts
motive: Intimidate the African American community of New Bedford Massachusetts.
weapdetail: Shotgun blasts were fired in rapid succession.
addnotes: This attack greatly increased the racial strife of the already violent conflict between the White and Black communities of New Bedford.  The mayor of New Bedford instituted a curfew in response to the riots that spread of control as a result to this attack.  Three Whites, Ralph Brown, Gary DesLauriers, and George Rose, were arrested and charged for the crime but were eventually acquitted.
scite1: Bill Kovach, "New Bedford Gets Curfew To Ease Racial Tensions," New York Times, July 13, 1970.
scite2: "New Bedford Negro Killed; 3 Are Held," New York Times, July 12, 1970.
scite3: "3 Youths Acquitted in Death of Negro in New Bedford," New York Times, May 19, 1971.

location: 1150-1160 North Sedgwick Street
summary: 7/17/1970: Chicago police officers Tony Rizzato and James Severin were killed by snipers while patrolling an open area at the Mother Cabrini Homes project in Chicago, Illinois, United States.  Two African Americans, Johnnie Veal and George Knights, were convicted of the murders.
target1: Chicago Police Officers patrolling the Mother Cabrini Homes project
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Two 30-30 rifles
propcomment: Windows shattered at surrounding buildings
addnotes: This was one of many sniping attacks against police in the Mother Cabrini Homes project.  The shots were fired from the sixth floor of an apartment building.  The perpetrators shot at the police as they attempted to tend to officers Severin and Rizzato.
scite1: "Chicago Sniping Kills 2 Policemen," New York Times, July 18, 1970.
scite2: "3 Youths Charged in Sniper Killings," Washington Post, July 19, 1970.
scite3: "2 Convicted of Chicago Sniping," Milwaukee Journal, August 26, 1971.

weapdetail: Car bomb

location: Intersection of Santa Clara Street and 11th Street
summary: 8/6/1970: Police Officer Richard Huerta was shot dead by Emile Thompson, a Black nationalist, while he was sitting in his car writing out a traffic ticket in San Jose, California, United Station.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Six shots fired
propcomment: Four shots hit officer Huerta
addnotes: Emile Thompson claimed that he carried out the attack to get back at the 'pigs' who had harassed him, noting that Officer Huerta represented all 'pigs.'  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in the Northern California area while they were making traffic stops (197008200003 and 197006190004).
scite1: Betty Barnacle, "Chief Opposes Parole for Cop Killer," Mercury News, June 4, 1995.
scite2: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.
scite3: "SJPD Fallen Officers: Officer Richard E. Huerta," San Jose Police Department, 2010. <http://www.sjpd.org/InsideSJPD/Fallen/Huerta.html>

weapdetail: Shotgun; Pistols

location: Parking lot of a West Point grocery store
summary: 8/15/1970: John Thomas was shot to death in his car in West Point, Mississippi, United States.  Thomas was a civil rights activist who previously led the campaign of a Black mayoral candidate.  The shooter, Seth Stanley, a White male, was found not guilty by means of self defense by an all-White jury.
addnotes: John Thomas was one of the accused perpetrators of 197001250001.  Seth Stanley was acquitted based on a successful argument of self defense, but it is important to note that John Thomas was shot as he was sitting in his truck.  A Black boycott of White-owned businesses in West Point was initiated as a result of this incident.
scite1: "Mississippi White Cleared in Killing," New York Times, October 12, 1971.
scite2: "Kin of NAACP Lobbyist Mitchell Wins Balto Primary Recount," New Pittsburgh Courier, October 10, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Third Avenue South
summary: 8/17/1970: Unknown perpetrators placed twenty sticks of dynamite in an a federal office building housing the Armed Forces Examination Center in Minneapolis, Minnesota, United States.  The resulting explosion knocked a night watchman unconscious and caused an estimated $500,000 in damage to the building.  Windows were shattered at buildings within a one block radius of the explosion.
target1: Armed Forces Examination Center, Minneapolis Minnesota
motive: Protest and sabotage the draft and the US Army
weapdetail: Twenty sticks of dynamite
propcomment: Extensive damage to the building and windows shattered at buildings within the surrounding area
addnotes: The federal office building had been the site of many anti-war demonstrations.  Following the explosion, police reported six false bomb threats in Minneapolis.  Police Officer Joseph Christy was knocked unconscious by the blast but he would recover from his injuries.
scite1: "Bombs Kill Officer, Rip U.S. Building," Washington Post, August 18, 1970.
scite2: "Minneapolis Bomb 'Very Well Placed,'" New York Times, August 19, 1970.
scite3: "Explosion Rips Federal Building At Minneapolis," The Evening Independent, August 17, 1970.

location: Intersection of Union Street and Jefferson Street
summary: 8/20/1970: Police Officer Ronald T. Tsukamoto was shot and killed by an unknown perpetrator in Berkeley, California, United States.  While writing a ticket for a motorcyclist, a man walked up to Officer Tsukamoto and shot him  twice with a revolver.  The perpetrator immediately jumped in a car driven by an African American male and sped away.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Revolver
addnotes: In 2005, police arrested Styles Frederick Price and Don Juan Warren Graphenreed, believing that Price carried out the murder and Graphenreed drove the getaway car.  However, the District Attorney of Alameda County declined to charge the suspects.  In 1970, there were two other police officers murdered by suspected Black Nationalists in the Northern California area while they were making traffic stops (197008060004 and 197006190004).
scite1: "Young Policeman Slain In Berkeley," New York Times, August 21, 1970.
scite2: Dorothy Vriend, "D.A. Declines To Charge Suspects In '70 Slaying," Contra Costa Times, August 19, 1970.
scite3: "Officer Slain Writing Ticket," St. Petersburg, August 21, 1970.

location: Restroom
summary: 8/22/1970: Gary Hogan, a suspected member of the Black Panthers Party, placed two time bombs in Dayton's Department Store in St. Paul, Minnesota, United States.  The first bomb detonated severely injuring one woman and causing damages to the restroom.  The second bomb, ten times more powerful that the first, was discovered and disarmed outside of the restroom by police.  It is believed that the second bomb was intended to kill police officers responding to the scene of the first bomb.
target1: St. Paul Police Officers responding to a bombing
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: One time bomb consisting of two sticks of dynamite and another time bomb consisting of twenty sticks of dynamite
propcomment: Restroom damaged
addnotes: Mary Peek was seriously injured but would survive her wounds.  Following the bombing, there were many bomb threats in St. Paul and Minneapolis.  Gary Hogan would also be convicted for planting a diversionary bomb as part of an attempted robbery of the First Grand Avenue Bank in St. Paul ten days later.
scite1: Nick Coleman, "Knowing My Place: The Victim of 8/22," St. Paul Pioneer Press, September 1, 2002.
scite2: "Woman Injured By Bomb Blast In Minnesota," Baltimore Sun, August 24, 1970.
scite3: "Bomb Blast Injured Minneapolis Shopper," Schenectady Gazette, August 24, 1970.

summary: 9/5/1970: Don Clayton McMain threw a hand grenade simulator into the DeWitt Police Station in DeWitt, Iowa, United States.  Two police officers were injured and the building sustained minor damages.
weapdetail: Hand Grenade Simulator
propcomment: Damaged front door and scorched floor
addnotes: Police officers Harry Roeder and Ben Burken, stationed in the rear of the police station, were injured in the bombing.  Authorities were unsure of the motive behind the attack.
scite1: "Bomb Rocks Manson Trial Building," New York Times, September 6, 1970.
scite2: "2 Hurt As Explosion Rips Police Station," Baltimore Sun, September 6, 1970.
scite3: "Two Hurt In Bomb Explosion," Herald-Journal, September 6, 1970.

location: Dorr Street
summary: 9/18/1970: Police Officer William Albert Miscannon was sitting in his police car in Toledo, Ohio, United States, near the headquarters of the Black Panther Party, when an unknown perpetrator walked up to his car and shot the officer three times.  Officer Miscannon was killed and his partner Officer Walter Shaw, who was also sitting in the car, was treated for shock.
target1: Toledo Police officer stationed outside of the Black Panther Party Headquarters
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Silver handgun fired three times
addnotes: Following the attack there was a gunfight between the Toledo Police and Black Panthers.  The Police raided the headquarters of the Black Panther party an hour after the incident which directly led to the demise of the BPP within Toledo.  John McClellan was accused of carrying out the attack, but after three trials, two of which resulted in hung juries, he was acquitted.
scite1: Agis Salpukas, "A Toledo Policeman Is Shot Dead in Patrol Car," New York Times, September 19, 1970.
scite2: Joshua Boak, "After 36 Years, Slain Officer's Daughter Feels Loss," Toledo Blade, February 22, 2007.
scite3: "Bloody Chapters Added To Panther Saga," Afro-American, September 26, 1970.

location: Side door of building
summary: 10/15/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a Police Storefront Center in Kansas City, Missouri, United States.  The Storefront Center was an experimental program focusing on improving relations between police and the African American community of Kansas City.  The building was damaged and Officers Kenneth Fleming and Charles Robinson were injured.
target1: Police Storefront Center, Kansas City Missouri
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Dynamite
propcomment: Door shattered and interior of building damaged
addnotes: Police were unsure whether the bomb was thrown or placed at the building.
scite1: Warren Weaver Jr., "President Stumps For Gore's Rival," New York Times, October 21, 1970.
scite2: Jerry Sullivan, "Bombing Raises Ire Of Black Community," Free Lance-Star, October 17, 1970.
scite3: "Nixon Sees 2 Wounded Policemen," Schenectady Gazette, October 21, 1970.

location: Washington Avenue
summary: 10/24/1970: Fifteen to eighteen Black militants, dressed in military fatigues and armed with rifles, opened fire on police headquarters in Cairo, Illinois, United States, three separate times during a six hour period.  Police were able to repel each of the three attacks.  One Black militant was injured and one bystander was hit by a stray bullet.  Buildings in the surrounding area were also damaged by bullets.  In response to this attack, the mayor claimed that there was an "open armed insurrection" taking place in Cairo.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Rifles
propcomment: Police station and buildings in surrounding area were damaged by bullets
addnotes: This might be part of a multiple attack with (197010240003) which took place in Cairo an hour earlier.  Snipers fired upon the police headquarters less than a week earlier (197010210003).  This first attack on the police station took place at 8:15 PM, the second attack took place at 10:15 PM, and the third attack took place at 2:10 AM on October 25th.  The final attack took thirty-five minutes and hundreds of rounds were fired.  Some of the gunmen emerged from the building that acted as the headquarters of the Black United Front, an organization which was directing a boycott of White owned businesses in Cairo at the time.  The Mayor of Cairo, Albert Thomas, believed that some of the Black militants were members of the Black Panther Party, however, the Black Panthers denied any involvement in the attacks.  State troopers were ordered into Cairo as a result of the attacks.
scite1: "Armed Negroes Attack Police Station in Cairo, Ill." New York Times, October 25, 1970.
scite2: "State Troopers on Duty in Cairo," New York Times, October 26, 1970.
scite3: "Riflemen Attack Police Station," Deseret News, October 24, 1970.

location: On conveyor belt
summary: 10/25/1970: Unknown perpetrators sent a mail bomb that exploded at the main post office in Washington D.C., United States.  The bomb caused no damage to the building, but one person was injured.  Minutes after the explosion, an anonymous phone caller told the post office, apparently unaware that the bomb already detonated, to evacuate the building because there was a bomb.  Authorities were unable to determine who the mailbomb was intended for.
weapdetail: The bomb was wrapped in brown paper and police discovered remnants of black powder, a battery, and a timing device.
propcomment: One bag of mail was destroyed
addnotes: Walter Smith, a post office employee, was treated for shock.
scite1: Henry Aubin and B. D. Colen, "Mail Parcel Explodes in Post Office," Washington Post, October 26, 1970.
scite2: "Package Explodes in D.C. Post Office," Baltimore Sun, October 26, 1970.
scite3: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.

location: Outside of Rainbow Gardens Bar
summary: 11/1/1970: African American Ronald Mitchell was killed in a drive-by shooting by suspected White Racists in New Castle, Pennsylvania, United States.  His death sparked violent race riots throughout the city.
motive: Suspected motive was to intimidate the African American community of New Castle Pennsylvania.
weapdetail: Drive-by shooting.
addnotes: This attack directly led to the outbreak of riots by the African American community of New Castle, Pennsylvania.
scite1: "Slaying Spurs Disorders," New York Times, November 2, 1970.
scite2: "Murder of Black Veteran Triggers New Castle Riot," New Pittsburg Courier, November 7, 1970.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 11/8/1970: Shortly after a lumber yard owned by Robert Cunningham, a former leader of a White vigilante group in Cairo, Illinois, United States, was set on fire, Wiley Anderson, an African American, was shot four times as he was walking in the Pyramid Court Housing Projects in Cairo.  Leaders of Cairo's African American community believed that Anderson was shot by White snipers firing indiscriminately into the predominantly Black housing projects.  Anderson died from his wounds two weeks later.
target1: African Americans walking in the Pyramid Court Housing Project in Cairo Illinois
motive: To kill African Americans
addnotes: This incident occurred a short time after the lumber yard of Cairo Illinois was set on fire (197011070002).  Wiley Anderson was a sergeant on leave from the army.  Members of the United Front, an organization directing an African American boycott of White owned business in Cairo, believed that the sniper fire was coming from two different directions.  The United Front also stated that Walter Garrett, who was walking with Wiley Anderson at the time, was also shot.  However, the police dispute this claim.  The FBI stated that there was no evidence that any federal statutes were violated and the police were unsure who shot Wiley Anderson.
scite1: "Cairo Plant Burns During Racial Clash," Washington Post, November 9, 1970.
scite2: "Panther Trial Judge Reverses Ruling, Allows Tapes," Washington Post, December 1, 1970.
scite3: "Cairo Disturbances," Reading Eagle, November 9, 1970.

location: 22nd Avenue S
summary: 11/15/1970: Police Officers John B. Horton and George A. Gatchel were beat up by African Americans in St. Petersburg, Florida, United States.  A car driving erratically was used to lure a police patrol car to a parking lot.  When Officers Horton and Gatchel got out of their car, two vehicles filled with ten to fifteen people sped into the lot.  Armed with rocks, bottles, plywood, and sticks the men got out of the car and injured both police officers.  The St. Petersburg Chief of Police  believed that the perpetrators were inspired by the many assaults on policemen by "revolutionary extremists" throughout the United States.
motive: To injure police
weapdetail: Fist, feet, rocks, bottles, sticks, and two-by-two piece of plywood
addnotes: Both officers received injuries to their faces.  Officer Horton required thirteen stitches and officer Gatchel required eight stitches.  Three days later, a White revolutionary firebombed a police car in St. Petersburg and stated his support for the "Black brothers" who beat up the police officers (197011180001).
scite1: Guy Kovner, "2 Policemen Are Beaten," St. Petersburg, November 18, 1970.
scite2: Mike Foley, "3 Arrested At Scene, 2 Policemen Beaten," Evening Independent, November 16, 1970.
scite3: "Two Men Plead Innocent," St. Petersburg, November 21, 1970.

location: The incident occurred at City Hall.
summary: 11/21/1970: Unknown perpetrators bombed a replica of the Liberty Bell that was located behind City Hall in Portland, Oregon, United States.  The blast destroyed the bell, damaged the front doors of City Hall, and shattered windows of buildings in the surrounding area.  A janitor was also injured by flying debris.
target1: Replica of Liberty Bell located at Portland City Hall
weapdetail: Dynamite bomb
propcomment: Liberty Bell destroyed, doors of City Hall damaged, furniture in City Hall upended, and windows within a three block radius of the blast were shattered.
addnotes: The bomb detonated at 2:55 AM.  No group claimed responsibility but authorities suspected that the perpetrators were part of the "protest community."
scite1: "Liberty Bell Copy Blown Up," New York Times, November 22, 1970.
scite2: Jim Redden, "Tumultuous Times Fattened the Files," Portland Tribune, October 30, 2009.
scite3: "Portland's City Hall Hit by Blast," Spokane Daily Chronicle, November 21, 1970.

location: The Bronx
summary: 1/15/1971: In a series of related incidents, an unknown perpetrator bombed a Marine Recruiting Station located in the National Bronx Bank Building in the Bronx, New York, United States.  Two people were injured and the bomb caused minor damage.
target1: Marine Recruiting Station housed in the National Bronx Bank Building
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
weapdetail: Pipe bomb placed in a shopping bag
propcomment: Slight damage to the recruiting station
addnotes: This is part of a multiple attack with 197101150005.  The bomb exploded at 11:00 AM.  The two people injured were Sgt. Leonard Godfrey and Pedro Torres.  Godfrey stated that he noticed a man place a shopping bag at the station which eventually blew up.
scite1: "2 Recruiting Stations Bombed in N.Y.," Washington Post, January 16, 1971.
scite2: "N.Y. Police Curtail Work In Protest Over Pay Issue," Baltimore Sun, January 16, 1971.
scite3: "Bombs Hit N.Y. Offices of Military," Afro-American, January 19, 1971.

location: Manhattan
summary: 1/24/1971: At around 8:00 AM, a member of the Black Liberation Army flagged down a police officer driving his radio car in Manhattan, New York, United States.  When the cop pulled over, the perpetrator began stabbing the officer with a knife.  The officer then shot and killed the assailant.  That morning, the New York Times received two anonymous calls stating that a New York policeman would be killed at 8:00 AM unless the BLA received $100,000.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Knife
addnotes: The police officer recovered from his stab wounds.  Josh Smith, a man purporting to be from the Black Liberation Army, called New York Channel 7 after the incident claiming that "no longer will the pig hatchet men plant their heels on our people."  He stated that the next two people to be targeted would be the commissioner and deputy commissioner of the New York Police Department.
scite1: Robert Daley, "Target Blue," Delacorte Press, 1973.
scite2: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Liberty City
summary: 2/20/1971: Miami Police Officer Victor Butler Jr. was ambushed by suspected members of the Black Afro-militant Movement (BAMM) in Miami, Florida, United States.  The bullets struck him in the chest and back and he died instantly.  BAMM members John Lane and John Murray Johnson were indicted of the murder but the charges were dropped when the police witness, and fellow BAMM member Jan Thurston, recanted his confession.  Police eventually indicted Thurston for the murder but charges against him were also dropped because a judged ruled that he was questioned without probable cause.
motive: To promote violence against the establishment
weapdetail: Two .30 caliber rifle slugs
addnotes: Victor Butler was an African American.  In his original confession, Thurston stated that he was in a car with 3-5 people that dropped Lane and Johnson off to commit the murder.  The Miami Police Department considers the case closed since Lane, Johnson, and Thurston, who the department believed to be involved in the incident, were arrested.
scite1: Dr. William Wilbanks, "Forgotten Heroes: Police Officers Killed in Dade County," Turner Publishing Company, 1996.

weapdetail: Explosive

location: 4792 Ottawa Ave.
summary: 4/2/1971: Police Officers Leonard A. Christiansen and Paul C. Teel were ambushed while on duty in Riverside, California, United States.  The officers, responding to a fake burglary call, were shot and killed as they got out of their car.  Police believed that the attack was carried out by three Black militants.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: Shotguns
propcomment: Police car damaged
addnotes: Officer Christiansen was killed instantly, while Officer Teel survived long enough to call for help, but died on his way to the hospital.  This incident took place during racial tension in Riverside California.  Three African Americans; Civil Rights leader Gary Lawton, Nehemiah Jackson and Larrie Gardner, were tried three times for the murders, but were never convicted.
scite1: Jon R. Waltz, "Beneath the Wheels of Justice; The Ambush Murders," Washington Post, November 25, 1979.
scite2: "Officer Leonard Christiansen and Officer Paul Teel," Riverside Police Department Safe In His Arms Memorial, 2009. <http://www.riversideca.gov/rpd/memorial/chrstn_teal.htm>.

location: Lover's Lane road between Plymouth and Ypsilanti Michigan
summary: 4/3/1971: Dr. R. Wiley Brownlee, high school principle and promoter of racial coexistence was struck down and kidnapped by members of the Ku Klux Klan in Ypsilanti, Michigan, United States.  Dr. Brownlee was released later in the night but not before he was tarred and feathered.
motive: Intimidate people who promote racial harmony
weapdetail: The shotguns were not fired.  The target was struck down either with the shotgun or by fist.
addnotes: The length of the kidnapping was estimated to be two hours.  In response to the attack, Dr. Brownlee jokingly stated that it made him the Blackest man in town.  Robert Miles, the leader of Michigan's KKK, and four others were indicted for the attack.  Robert Miles was convicted.  He was also convicted for incident 197108300002.
scite1: "High School Principal 'Tarred and Feathered,'" Atlanta Daily World, April 4, 1971.
scite2: "Arrest Held Stunt," Washington Post, June 24, 1972.
scite3: "Klan Leader Convicted," Call and Post, November 17, 1973.

summary: 4/19/1971: The Armed Commandos of Liberation claimed responsibility for detonating two bombs in American owned businesses at the El Comandante Shopping Center in San Juan, Puerto Rico.  The bombs caused extensive damage and three people were injured by flying glass.
corp1: American owned business in Puerto Rico
target1: Franklin's Women's Apparel store and Thom McCan shoe store, San Juan Puerto Rico
motive: To protest United States owned businesses in Puerto Rico
weapdetail: Two bombs
propcomment: Extensive damage
addnotes: The bombs were placed in a Thom McCan shoe store and Franklin's Women's Apparel store.  Furthermore, other United States establishments such as Woolworth's, CIT Finance Company, and Burger King were damaged in the incident.
scite1: "Catholics Closing 56 Schools," Washington Post, April 19, 1971.
scite2: "Blasts Strike San Juan," New York Times, April 19, 1971.
scite3: "Toward People's War for Independence and Socialism in Puerto Rico: In Defense of Armed Struggle," Documents and CommuniquÃ©s from the Revolutionary Public Independence Movement and the Armed Clandestine Movement, January 1987.

summary: 4/29/1971: Christopher Brian Cowsar went to the Air Force Recruiting Station in Berkeley, California, United States and stabbed Air Force Sergeant Rogers S. Mobley to death.  During the incident Cowsar screamed, "he's sending people to Vietnam.  He's got to die."
target1: Air Force Recruiting Sergeant in Berkeley California
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
weapdetail: Five-inch hunting knife
addnotes: Christopher Brian Cowsar was a former marine.  He was captured by two men who rushed to save Sergeant Mobley after they heard him screaming.
scite1: "Bank, Store Bombed, Trucks Burned in L. A.," Washington Post, May 1, 1971.
scite2: "Recruiter Slain On Job, Hero Killed In Hold-Up," Afro-American, May 8, 1971.
scite3: "Air Force Recruiter Stabbed," Lodi News-Sentinel, May 1, 1971.

summary: 5/4/1971: Unknown perpetrators attempted to firebomb an Air Force Recruiting Station in Chico, California, United States.  However, the bomb fizzled out before it was able to ignite.
target1: Air Force Recruiting Station, Chico California
motive: To protest the War in Vietnam and the draft
weapdetail: Firebomb
addnotes: Hours after this incident, a bomb was detonated at a Bank of America branch in Chico California (197105050003).  A day later, a bookstore in Chico California was firebombed (197105050004).
scite1: "Power Station, Refinery Bombed on Coast," Baltimore Sun, May 7. 1971.
scite2: "Bombs Hit California Businesses," Sarasota Herald-Tribune, May 6, 1971.
scite3: "Power Station, Book Store Hit by Bombs," The Day, May 6, 1971.

summary: 5/6/1971: An explosive device detonated within the vicinity of Military Trucks at the Naval Ammunition Depot in Hawthorne, Nevada, United States.  Private Charles Henderson was killed and Lance Corporal Charles Bauer was injured.
target1: Military Trucks at Naval Ammunition Depot in Hawthorne Nevada
motive: To protest and sabotage the US Military
weapdetail: Explosive device
addnotes: There are conflicting reports as to whether authorities believed that the explosive device was set off intentionally due to sabotage or if the incident was accidental.
scite1: "The Nation: 16 Detroit Police Seized in Gambling Drive," Los Angeles Times,, May 7, 1971.
scite2: Marcia McKnight Trick, "Chronology of Incidents of Terroristic, Quasi-Terroristic, and Political Violence in the United States: January 1965 to March 1976," National Advisory Committee on Criminal Justice Standards and Goals: Report of the Task Force on Disorders and Terrorism, 1976.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

location: Manhattan
summary: 5/19/1971: Members of the Black Liberation Army shot and wounded two police officers, Thomas P. Curry and Nicholas J. Binetti, in Manhattan, New York, United States.  The officers were guarding the home of New York District Attorney Frank Hogan when they saw a car going the wrong way down a one-way street.  When the officers caught up with the vehicle six blocks away, the perpetrators fired shots into the police car.  The radio car was riddled with bullets and the windshield was shattered.
target1: Police officers guarding the home of New York District Attorney Frank Horgan
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: .45 caliber submachine gun
propcomment: Windshield of police car shattered
addnotes: The Black Liberation Army claimed the attack in letters to the New York Times and New York radio station WLIB.  The machine gun used in the incident was discovered by police while arresting members of the Black Liberation Army in a robbery two weeks later (197106050002).  Richard Moore (Dhoruba al-Mujahid Bin Walid) was convicted of the incident in 1973 after two previous trials went to hung juries.  However, the New York Supreme Court reversed the conviction in 1990 due to the prosecutions failure to disclose evidence to the defense.
scite1: Robert Daley, "Target Blue," Delacorte Press, 1973.
scite2: Martin Arnold, "Hunto On for 2 Would-Be 'Cop Killers,'" New York Times, May 21, 1971.
scite3: Ronald Sullivan, "Court Erupts As Judge Frees An Ex-Panther," New York Times, March 23, 1990.

location: 1400 Washington St.
summary: 5/29/1971: Black militants fired into the Police Headquarters of Cairo, Illinois, United States, injuring a police officer.  Following the shooting, police officers noticed four men armed with guns across the street from the station.  The officers fired on the assailants initiating a shoot-out that lasted two hours.  Two additional policemen sustained bullet wounds while all four perpetrators eventually escaped.
motive: To kill police
weapdetail: .30 caliber bullets
propcomment: Door damaged
addnotes: The three injured policemen were Hershell Hoppe, Larry Modlin, and Terry Pigg.  The perpetrators were spotted near St. Columbia Church which had served as a headquarters for the Black United Front, an organization which was directing a boycott of White owned businesses in Cairo.
scite1: "3 Wounded in Cairo Shootout," Chicago Tribune, May 31, 1971.
scite2: "Cairo Police Claim Station Is Attacked," Hartford Courant, May 31, 1971.
scite3: "Cairo Radio Operator Shot, In Fair Condition," Southeast Missourian, June 1, 1971.

location: Oklahoma University
summary: 11/17/1971: Unknown perpetrators set fire to four buildings on the Oklahoma University campus in Norman, Oklahoma, United States.  Two other incendiary devices failed to ignite.  The Bizel Memorial Library was also vandalized.  In total, twenty-seven people were injured and the buildings sustained an estimated $200,000 in damages.
target1: Storage building, Walker Tower, Wilson Center Cafeteria, Building 8, Microbiology building, and the Bizel Memorial Library at Oklahoma University
motive: This incident occurred during a period of intense racial conflict on the Oklahoma University campus
weapdetail: Explosive wick incendiary devices taped to doors of building.  Library cards dumped on the floor and soaked with glue and molasses.
propcomment: Building 8 destroyed. Walker Tower, Wilson Center Cafeteria, and Storage building damaged.
addnotes: At the time, African American students at Oklahoma University believed that many "racial atrocities" were being committed on campus.  The first fire began at a book storage building at 10:30 PM.  At 4:30 AM, on November 18, two fires simultaneously ignited at the Wilson Center Cafeteria and Walker Tower.  A fire was set at Building 8 on south campus at 5:20 AM.  Failed incendiary devices were also discovered at the Microbiology building and Campus Police Building.  Five days before the incident, the University Administration Building was firebombed (197111120002).  Hours before the incident, there was a shooting at the Black People's Union (197111170002).
scite1: "Arsonists Are Hunted At Okla. U.," Washington Post, November 19, 1971.
scite2: "Probe Arson in OU Fires," The Fort Scott Tribune, November 18, 1971.
scite3: "OU Damages $200,000, 27 Hurt; Vandals Sought," Lawrence Journal-World, November 19, 1971.

summary: 2/1/1972: Unknown perpetrators bombed Central High School in Jackson, Mississippi, United States.  There were no casualties but a cabinet was destroyed resulting in an estimated $100 in damages.
weapdetail: Small homemade bomb
propcomment: Cabinet destroyed
addnotes: The bomb detonated around 12:00 PM.  The racial makeup of the school was half White and half Black.
scite1: "School Blast Investigated," Reading Eagle, February 2, 1972.
scite2: Anthony Ripley, "Officials Voice Concern at Rash of School Bombings," New York Times, May 28, 1972.

location: The Bronx
summary: 3/16/1972:  Four members of the Black Liberation Army robbed a Bankers Trust Company branch in the Bronx, New York, United States.  The perpetrators stole $180,000.  When police officers arrived on the scene a brief shoot-out occurred.  Police officer Robert Kirsh was wounded and the assailants were able to escape.
target1: Bankers Trust Company branch at 2104 Crotona Parkway Bronx New York
motive: The Black Liberation Army stole money in order to support their armed struggle.  BLA members believed that armed struggle was the only means by which the Black Nationalist movement could break the psychological-class chains of 20th century enslavement.
weapdetail: Guns
propcomment: Money stolen and windshield of police car shattered
addnotes: The incident occurred around 9:40 AM.  One of the perpetrators was Black Liberation Army member Twymon Ford Myers who would later be killed in a shoot-out with police.  It is unknown if the money stolen from the robbery was divvied up between the perpetrators or used to fund the causes of the Black Liberation Army.
scite1: "Policeman Is Hurt In $90,000 Holdup Of Bank in Bronx," New York Times, March 17, 1972.
scite2: John T. McQuiston, "Fugitive Black Militant Killed, 4 Wounded in Bronx Shootout," New York Times, November 15, 1973.
scite3: "Suspect in Kidnapping Sought In the Killing of Two Policemen," New York Times, December 29, 1972.

location: 1600 Bellflower Blvd.
summary: 4/18/1972: The Jewish Defense League detonated a bomb in Bellflower, California, United States.  Two people were injured and the bomb caused an estimated $250,000 in damages to surrounding buildings.
target1: Building containing Castlehead Escrow, Bruce Mulhearn Realty Office, and Lana's Kopy Kat Print Office.
motive: Protest business prejudiced against Jews
weapdetail: Explosive device thrown from car
propcomment: Building containing realty office, print shop and escrow office destroyed.  Beauty shop extensively damaged.  Windows shattered in surrounding buildings.
addnotes: The bomb detonated around 11:40 PM. Two long haired youths in a car was were witnessed throwing the bomb in front of the Escrow Office.  The bomb was burning in a paper bag before it exploded.  The power of the device was equivalent to six sticks of dynamite.  Minutes after the bombing, the United Press International received a call claiming that the bomb was for "Jesus freaks and prejudiced against Jews."  The caller was unclear about the target of the attack but shouted "never again" before hanging up.  "Never again" was a slogan of the Jewish Defense League.  The JDL detonated a bomb in the Los Angeles area two weeks earlier (197204050001).
scite1: "Bomb Destroys 4 Offices In Suburban Los Angeles," New York Times, April 20, 1972.
scite2: David Rosenzweig, "Bombing in Bellflower May Be Linked to Housing Controversy," Los Angeles Times, April 20, 1972.
scite3: "Bomb Blast Wrecks Building," The Bulletin, April 19, 1972.

location: Manhattan
summary: 5/27/1972: Unknown perpetrators bombed two buildings at Columbia University in Manhattan, New York, United States.  There were no casualties and the resulting fires caused only minor damage.
target1: Pupin Physics Hall and the School of International Affairs at Columbia University
motive: Protest the War in Vietnam
weapdetail: Time bombs
propcomment: Light damage to Physics Hall and rug damage at School of International Affairs
addnotes: The bomb at the School of International Affairs detonated at 1:45 AM and the bomb at the Pupin Physics Hall detonated at 2:05 AM.  Both buildings were the target of anti-war protests.  An anonymous female called the Columbia security office warning that bombs would detonate at the Physics Hall, School of International Affairs, the administration center, the Low Memorial Library, and the law school.  There were no bombs discovered at the latter three buildings.
scite1: "2 Blasts Damage Separate Buildings In Columbia Area" New York Times, May 27, 1972.

target1: F. W. Woolworth Company, 144 East 44th Street
motive: To support Puerto Rican independence from the United States on the day the issue was being discussed in the United Nations

In the call, they stated that there were also bombs placed in the United Nations, but this proved to be false.
